triples.name: Large language model
triples.relevance: LLMs trained on code-completion are the foundation for the Code as Policies approach to generate robot policy code.

triples.name: Few-shot learning
triples.relevance: Few-shot prompting enables LLMs to learn new robot control tasks from minimal examples of language commands and policy code.

triples.name: Python (programming language)
triples.relevance: Python is the primary language used by the LLM to write robot policy code and interface with control APIs.

triples.name: Robotics
triples.relevance: The paper demonstrates robot control applications across multiple real robot platforms.

triples.name: Object detection
triples.relevance: Object detectors provide perception outputs that policy code processes to enable vision-based robot control.

triples.name: NumPy
triples.relevance: NumPy library is used by generated policy code to perform arithmetic and numerical computations on robot sensor data.

triples.name: Motion planning
triples.relevance: Trajectory-based control and waypoint-based policies represent new approaches to robot motion planning using LLM-generated code.

triples.name: Code generation
triples.relevance: The paper proposes hierarchical code generation as a novel technique where LLMs recursively define undefined functions to solve more complex robot control problems.

triples.name: Natural language processing
triples.relevance: NLP enables the system to interpret natural language commands and convert them into executable robot policy code.

triples.name: Pick and place
triples.relevance: Vision-based pick and place is demonstrated as a new application of LLM-generated robot policies.
